summary: This document is a reproduction of 5 C.F.R. ยง 2635.101, the 'Basic obligation of public service' from the Standards of Ethical Conduct for Employees of the Executive Branch. It outlines general ethical principles for federal employees, including prohibitions on conflicts of interest, accepting gifts, using public office for private gain, and giving preferential treatment. It is part of the Epstein case document set, likely included as a reference for ethical standards relevant to the conduct of government officials in the case.
keyFacts: The document is the official U.S. Government ethics regulation (5 C.F.R. ยง 2635.101) defining the basic obligations of federal executive branch employees.
It establishes core principles including placing loyalty to the Constitution and laws above private gain, avoiding conflicts of interest, and not using public office for private gain.
It explicitly prohibits employees from accepting gifts from persons or entities seeking official action or doing business with their agency.
The regulation mandates impartiality, stating employees 'shall not give preferential treatment to any private organization or individual.'
Its inclusion in the Epstein case document set suggests it is being referenced as a standard against which the conduct of government officials connected to the case may be measured.
